Grandfather David Thomas and our grandmother. He was the survivor of the Civil War and the notorious Andersonville Prison. Later he became an unusually successful school teacher. Grandmother was a poetess....

Note: These are a couple of pictures of my noisy kid sister. One was taken a month ago in front of our apartment on Nassau St. and the other of the school where she attends. They call it the model school but I'm sure they haven't any teachers there that could touch you [photographs accompanied by a letter to Frances Ryan, 1917]
Photograph from China Essay Contest Dinner with Note 5.11

Note: AWARD PRIZES AT CHINA ESSAY CONTEST DINNER Eighty distinguished guests, all of them especially interested in China and in Far Eastern affairs, gathered at the Ford Motor pavilion on September 18 for a formal dinner in honor of the Contest's judges, prizewinners, and the contest's financial sponsor, W.D. Pawley. Lowell Thomas presented his newscast as part of the banquet, over which he presided. Fred L. Black, director of the Ford pavilion, acted as host. Pherbia Thomas Thornburg, contest director, presented the first three prizes to Minerva S. Desing of Collingswood, N.J.; Richard E. Curl of Edison, O.; and Helen Averitt of Pasadena, Calif. The spacious Ford Executive Lounge was especially decorated with Chinese screens, tapestries, modern paintings and statuary. Table decorations were Chinese junks, night-blooming water lilies in natural wood bowls, and silk Chinese and American flags. Costumed Chinese girls gave corsages to women guests and boutonnieres to men. Guests entered through a Dragon Gate; as they sat at table they could see, through the great glass wall of the Lounge, the Ford pavilion terrace which for the occasion had been transformed into a Chinese garden at Autumn Festival time, with trees, a scenic backdrop, a compound wall, gay lanterns, and dainty costumed Chinese girls having tea. A Chinese orchestra played. Favors, supplied by the China Essay Contest, were handsome souvenir books especially published and bound in brocade treaty silk. In this photo (left to right) are: Lowell Thomas, Rear Admiral H. E. Yarnell and Pearl Buck
Photograph from China Essay Contest Dinner with Note 5.13

Pawley. Lowell Thomas presented his newscast as part of the banquet, over which he presided. Fred L. Black, director of the Ford pavilion, acted as host. A Chinese orchestra played. Favors, supplied by the China Essay Contest, were handsome souvenir books especially published and bound in brocade treaty silk. In this photo (left to right) are: Pherbia Thomas Thornburg, W. D. Pawley, Mrs. William Brown Meloney (from Newsweek magazine), Rear Admiral Yarnell (in back) and Lowell Thomas
